thread.title: UK tells Britons in Russia: be aware of harassment, don't talk politics

title: UK tells Britons in Russia: be aware of harassment, don't talk politics
text: March 14, 2018 / 3:12 PM / in 15 minutes UK tells Britons in Russia: be aware of harassment, don't talk politics Reuters Staff 1 Min Read LONDON (Reuters) - Britain has told its citizens travelling to Russia to be aware of anti-British sentiment and harassment and avoid commenting on politics, as relations between the two countries sour over the poisoning of a former Russian double agent. Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May addresses the House of Commons on her government's reaction to the poisoning of former Russian intelligence officer Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury, in London, March 14, 2018. Parliament TV handout via REUTERS The Foreign Office updated its travel advice on Wednesday after Prime Minister Theresa May said Russia was behind the attack on Sergei Skripal and his daughter with nerve agent, and expelled 23 diplomats. Russia denies responsibility. “Due to heightened political tensions between the UK and Russia, you should be aware of the possibility of anti-British sentiment or harassment at this time,” the Foreign Office said in a travel advisory. “You’re advised to remain vigilant, avoid any protests or demonstrations and avoid commenting publicly on political developments,” it added. British police have estimated that 10,000 to 20,000 British soccer fans were expected to travel to Russia in the Summer for the finals of the World Cup. Reporting by Kate Holton; writing by Alistair Smout; editing by Stephen Addison
